author: tmichael
title: Brits feared among New Zeland bus crash victims as seven seriously injured on luxury cruise day trip
text:
CRUISE TRAGEDY Brits feared among New Zeland bus crash victims as seven seriously injured on luxury cruise day trip 
Tragedy for passengers on Celebrity cruise line's Solstice liner during excursion near South Island town of Akaroa BY TOM MICHAEL Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments FEARS are growing for Brits aboard a luxury cruise ship after passengers were caught up in a tragedy in New Zealand today. 
At least two people are fighting for their lives and five more are seriously injured after their coach collided with a car during a day trip to the country’s South Island. NZ Herald The coach carrying 32 people plummeted 100ft down a steep hillside NZ Herald Emergency workers rushed at least seven people to hospital with serious injuries NZ Herald 7 Firemen had to cut people out of the car which collided with the bus 
The coach was carrying people travelling on the Celebrity cruise line’s Solstice liner who were enjoying an excursion in the beautiful hills near Christchurch. 
It is not yet known if any of the critically and seriously injured casualties are British. 
But hundreds of UK nationals are among the estimated 2,850 passengers on board the vessel. 
The bus slammed into a car on a twisting stretch of road winding through the mountain range near the coastal town of Akaroa where the Solstice had docked for the day. 
The coach was sent careering off 100ft down a steep embankment into the undergrowth. 
Motorists who were first on the scene scrambled down the bank to help the injured from the mangled wreckage as trapped tourists screamed for help. 
Passengers – some paying nearly £20,000 for luxury suites aboard the ship – had been taken ashore this morning for various excursions on a fleet of coaches. 
The horror crash happened as the coaches were returning to Akaroa, where a fleet of small boats was lined up to ferry them back to the ship. Were you on board the ship? Do you know anyone involved in the crash? Contact Tom Michael at tom.michael@thesun.co.uk or ring 0207 782 4368 
The liner had been due to set sail to its next port of call, Dunedin, at 7pm local time – 6am UK time. 
But as news of the tragedy filtered through, the captain announced that the sailing was to be delayed. 
Passengers on board the Solstice sat in stunned silence as they anxiously awaited news on their friends. 
Many British passengers rushed to email and phone relatives back home in the UK to reassure them they were safe. Brits feared among New Zealand bus crash victims on luxury cruise day trip 
One UK passenger who asked not to be named said: "Everyone is in shock – many of us had been on the coach trips that were laid on to take us to places like Christchurch when the ship moored at Akaroa this morning. 
"People had a lovely day – the weather was hot and sunny – and we all got back on board the boat ready to enjoy our evening dinner when the news came through. 
"We are all in a state of shock and the news about the victims doesn't sound good. 
"We have been told that six people are in hospital and they are very seriously injured. We are all praying for them and hoping they pull through. 
"I don't know if any of them are British but there are loads of people from the UK on board the ship and many would have been among people making the coach excursions ashore today. 
"People had been looking forward to this holiday for months – for this to happen is dreadful." The Solstice – currently touring New Zealand and Australia – left Auckland after picking up passengers last week. 
Its first port of call was Tarangua, where many passengers took coach trips to see where the Hobbit houses were built for the Lord of the Rings films. 
It then sailed on to Napier and Wellington, arriving in Akaroa today. 
The passage through the mountains to Akaroa from Christchurch features perilous hairpin bends where there is barely enough room for two cars to pass each other. 
The bus, carrying more than two dozen passengers from the cruise ship, collided with a car on the winding road. 
Reports said the coach careered off down a steep bank and ended up in the undergrowth just after 5pm local time. NZ Herald 7 The bus smashed into a car before careering off the road to the right of the image 
St John Ambulance Controller Sean Lester said the two people fighting for their lives have been rushed to Christchurch Hospital by helicopter. 
Another with serious injuries was also transferred to hospital by chopper, while four people seriously hurt and one person with moderate injuries were taken by ambulance. 
The remaining 26 occupants of the vehicles involved – who either had minor injuries or escaped unscathed – had boarded a different bus, Lester said. 
They were taken to Akaroa Fire Station for further assessment by paramedics. 
Firefighters had to cut at least one person from the car and the bus driver out of the wreckage, Fairfax reported. 
Three fire engines, at least four ambulances and at least one police car attended the scene. 
Senior Sergeant Vaughn Lapslie, of Christchurch Police, said there were 32 people on the bus at the time. 
He was unable to confirm the nationalities of those involved. NZ Herald Two people hug each other at the scene of the horror crash near Akaroa 
A staff member at the nearby Hilltop Tavern said he took water to the victims. 
Camera operator Matthew Simons said he could see the bus about 160ft down the embankment and a blue wagon-like Toyota on the road. 
Simons said he believed he'd seen one of the bus passengers emerging but was unsure. 
There was "a whole heap of firefighters working around the bus". 
Firefighters had to use cutting tools to open the roof of the small, light blue car. 
Debris from the smash was strewn across the road and the front of the car was mangled. 
Pieces of the car were left lined up on the side of the road, resting on a bank. NZ Herald 7 The driver of the bus is understood to have been cut out by emergency workers 
Photos from the scene also showed the wreckage of the bus lying on its side among the foliage. 
People could be seen scrambling to get to the bus to help those trapped inside. 
A crowd gathered at the police cordon around the next bend in the road, where three white buses and several cars were pulled over. 
A worker at the Hilltop Tavern said the crash happened just around the corner from the bar but said he couldn't see the scene from where he was. 
A customer told him multiple people were injured. 
He said: “The hill is steep and if a bus went down there, it would be of concern.” 
The Christchurch-Akaroa Rd is now closed between Summit Rd and Barry's Bay Rd, with cops re-directing motorists. 
The Commercial Vehicle Investigation Unit and the Serious Crash Unit have been advised. NZ Herald 7 Debris lies scattered across the road next to the mangled remains of a blue Toyota 
Tragedy has struck Celebrity Solstice – which has capacity to carry 2,850 passengers and 1,250 crew members – on New Zealand roads three times in the last few months. 
A Canadian passenger from the ship was severely injured when he was hit by a campervan while cycling with his partner on Otago Peninsula last week. He has since recovered. 
And an elderly American woman who was on board in November was killed while riding a bike in Tauranga the day the ship arrived in the city. 
The 71-year-old was struck by a truck near the harbour bridge. 
The same afternoon a bus carrying passengers from the same vessel collided with a car on State Highway 29. The car's driver died after the crash, but nobody on the bus was injured.
